race.name: Rasputitsa
race.tagline: Vermont's early season mud fest—46 miles of Class 4 roads, self-supported suffering, and guaranteed mud.

climate.description: 35-55°F, 40% rain chance, mud guaranteed. 'Rasputitsa' = Russian for 'mud season'.

terrain.surface: 70% dirt roads, 20% gravel, 10% pavement. Class 4 roads = unmaintained. April = mud. Self-supported (NO aid stations). 5,000 ft elevation over 46 miles. Technical rating: 4/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Rasputitsa is Vermont's early season mud fest—46 miles of Class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt), 5,000 ft elevation, self-supported (NO aid stations), and guaranteed mud. Founded 2016, 10th anniversary 2026. 'Rasputitsa' is Russian for 'mud season'. April in Vermont = mud. Class 4 roads = technical. Self-supported = hardcore. 600+ riders. Burke Northeast Kingdom. If you want Vermont hardcore suffering, this is it. If you want smooth gravel and aid stations, run away.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Rasputitsa is Vermont mud masochism. If you want technical Class 4 roads, self-supported adventure, and guaranteed mud, this is bucket-list. If you want smooth gravel and support, skip it. Mud is the point. Embrace it or stay home.

logistics.lodging_note: Burke small Northeast Kingdom town. Book early. Limited lodging.
logistics.travel_summary: Burlington airport 50 miles. Rental car needed. Burke small town—book lodging early. Day-before packet pickup. Race Saturday.
logistics.food_options: NONE on course (self-supported). Post-race party at finish.

course_description.character: 46 miles of Vermont Class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt). 5,000 ft elevation. Self-supported (NO aid). Mud guaranteed (April). Technical rating: 4/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Class 4 Roads + Mud
suffering_zones.description: Unmaintained dirt roads. April mud guaranteed. Bikes clog. Technical.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 40-50mm tires. Aggressive tread. Carry spares. Accept mud. Pace conservatively.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 20-40: Burke Mountain Area
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Low gears. Walk if needed. Self-supported means manage energy.

suffering_zones.name: Self-Supported: All Miles
suffering_zones.description: NO aid stations. Carry food, water, spares. Bonk = DNF.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Carry 2+ bottles, food for 4-6 hours, spare tube, CO2, multitool.

course_description.signature_challenge: April mud + self-supported + Class 4 technical roads. Mud is guaranteed, aid is not.

history.origin_story: Rasputitsa founded 2016. Named for Russian word meaning 'mud season'. Vermont early season mud fest. 600+ riders. Burke Northeast Kingdom. Self-supported. 10th anniversary 2026.
history.reputation: Vermont hardcore mud fest. Self-supported. Grassroots.

logistics.explanation: Jay Peak Resort hosting provides venue infrastructure, but course conditions create operational uncertainty. Newcombep warns 'the start for the 70k can be a bit brutal with the dh then immediate climbing stretch. Start line is a bit of a free forall and you could be leap frogging alot of groups.' Dean Havelock notes 'within the first two miles of the race the entire pack was forced off their bikes for ankle/axle deep mud.'

length.explanation: FergusYL 'felt great, set all-time power records for 20 minutes up through 2 hours, then ran out of gas with 4 or 5 miles to go' after underfeeding over 3.5 hours. Newcombep describes 'final 7ish miles are brutal' with 'always up or down never seems to be any flat stretchs.' Short enough that proper fueling strategy becomes the deciding factor rather than endurance capacity. More compact than Grinduro. As FergusYL puts it: "My biggest regret of last year was under fueling. I felt great, set all-time power records for 20 minutes up through 2 hours, then (after a drinking a bottle and a half of Gatorade and eating maybe ha..."

technicality.explanation: Chris Burati describes Cyberia as 'the dreaded mud/ice/snow mix segment, which is the last third of an already nasty, steep, somewhat technical climb' where 'I couldn't go any easier other than hard or else I would become unseated and would need to walk.' Equipment casualties include brake failure, derailleur hangers, and Chris Burati hitting 'a blast hole in the dirt and my bars rotated 30 degrees downwards.' Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands. As Chris Burati puts it: "I hit the gas, and hit the gas, and hit the gas. It was about 9 miles to Cyberia, the dreaded mud/ice/snow mix segment, which is the last third of an already nasty, steep, somewhat technical climb, an..."

elevation.explanation: Dean Havelock measured 'about 5500 vertical feet of climbing from start to finish' over 55 miles with top finishers maintaining '18-21mph over the entire course with 7K of climbing.' FergusYL warns 'the end is rough. There are some steep climbs, and the final half-mile? is a steep, sandy uphill to Burke lodge.' Chris Burati's Cyberia climb was 'a grind' requiring sustained power to avoid walking. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Newcombep puts it: "The start for the 70k can be a bit brutal with the dh then immediate climbing stretch."

climate.explanation: Petals survived 2019's 'worst weather conditions in the history of the race' with 'pouring rain, sleet, snow, hail. Temp never cracked 40F' causing hypothermia DNFs and 75% of non-finishers stopping by mile 20. 2018 featured 30+ minutes 'trudging through fairly deep snow' on cross-country ski trails. Even mild years bring unpredictable conditions—FergusYL's 2023 forecast of 60s-70s became race day '35-40ish' degrees. Among the most weather-friendly events, easier than Badlands. As Dean Havelock puts it: "Around the time of the start gun, snow started to pick up in an angry fashion. It was just above freezing with steady wind blowing snow in sideways, making my 9am start time feel like an eternity away..."

altitude.explanation: Burke, Vermont sits at typical New England elevations with no altitude considerations. The suffering comes from weather, mud, and gradient rather than thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Equipment failures compound the wilderness experience—Petals 'no longer had a front brake and barely any back brake' by mile 30, while Matthew Vandivort made 'the super wise decision to put slick touring tires on my bike' for icy conditions. Steve Rousseau's group spent 30 minutes 'trudging through fairly deep snow for what seemed to be forever' after a wrong turn into cross-country ski trails.

prestige.explanation: FergusYL describes the atmosphere as reminiscent of 'mountain bike races in the early 90's where people are chatty and supportive, and it's a real festive atmosphere.' CycloWorld calls it 'legendary' after 10 years, but the race philosophy explicitly states 'if you're looking for podiums and podium-placed winners, look elsewhere.' The focus remains on community participation rather than elite competition.

race_quality.explanation: Course uncertainties create operational challenges—Steve Rousseau's 2018 race included an unplanned 30-minute snow trudge after organizers directed racers onto cross-country ski trails. Petals notes strong sweep vehicle support providing Hotshot for cramping riders and multiple check-ins. The race delivers on its promise of difficulty, though weather-dependent course decisions affect execution consistency.

experience.explanation: Matthew Vandivort describes aid stations with 'someone had not just baked several dozen cookies for the racers but they also setup a mini-bar in their front yard' offering 'Woodford Reserve to PBR at the midway point and Fireball pickleback shots in the final miles.' Yetis offer 'shots of maple syrup to riders in eco-friendly, toss-away glasses made from ice' while 'rainbow-colored, grinning unicorns' provide homemade cookies.

community.explanation: The race philosophy states 'the largest award goes to the Lanterne Rouge recipient'—last finisher wins biggest prize. All proceeds support Little Bellas mentoring program, raising $19,000+ annually. When Anthony Moccia faced cancer, the community rallied with benefit concerts. Chris Hadgis praises volunteers as 'cheerful, supportive, out there spending their day helping crazy bike riders.' As FergusYL puts it: "Last year's was my first bike race in ~15 years or so, and it immediately felt like home."

field_depth.explanation: The race draws participants across skill levels from mountain bikers like Evan Chismark on a Yeti Arc hardtail to competitive riders setting power records, but competitive depth remains unclear. Dean Havelock notes top finishers maintained 18-21mph averages, while the philosophy emphasizes personal challenge over racing others. The 2019 extreme weather saw 'even some of the pros needed to stop due to hypothermia.' Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three. As Dean Havelock puts it: "The pack caught me again carrying me through the middle of the race. Around mile 35 dropped to load up on calories missed earlier in the race."

value.explanation: Founders emphasize 'modest price tag of early-day gravel' with explicit commitment to 'not using this construct to make money.' The multi-day festival includes Pearl Jam tribute bands, homemade aid station cookies, and post-race spreads at Jay Peak Resort. FergusYL recommends taking 'full advantage of the rest stops' which feature 'good snacks, plus whiskey and maple syrup at the last one or two.'

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $80-$120. Jay Peak Resort hosting provides lodging but likely at resort pricing during race weekend. Equipment debates become costly—Matthew Vandivort's tire choice proved inadequate while Scott Miller 'swapped out the MTB tires for some gravel tires' and later concluded 'if I ever do Rasputitsa again, I will ride a gravel bike.' Chris Burati's wrong cassette choice (11-28 instead of 11-32) demonstrates gear-specific requirements.

final_verdict.one_liner: Vermont's 10-year-old mud lottery where 5,000 feet of climbing meets April's bipolar weather and your cross training actually matters.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can handle 46 miles of sustained climbing in conditions that range from perfect to apocalyptic, Rasputitsa delivers authentic Northeast Kingdom suffering without the ego. The 5,000 feet of elevation isn't negotiable, and April weather means you might get snow, mud, or sunshine—sometimes all three. Skip this if you need predictable conditions or hate climbing.
final_verdict.alternatives: Vermont Overland offers similar Vermont grit with more distance options, while Dirty Kanza (Unbound) gives you comparable difficulty without the elevation. For pure climbing punishment, try Gravel Worlds if you want the suffering with better weather odds.

a close up of a cement surface with small rocks

videos.title: Rasputitsa 2019
videos.description:
Rasputitsa is a Russian word for the mud season during spring when the roads become impassable. It is also a Gravel Race in East Burke, Vermont where people test their mental as well as physical abilities.

This year was a true mental battle, to choose to start the race and to stay in as it rained, snowed, and sleeted on us. Wet gear, frozen fingers and toes, 42 miles, and 4700ft of climbing. All in temps of 37F (3C) to 41F (5C) degrees.

This video is going to have a lot of water and mud on the lens but you'll get the idea. It was tough.

Follow along @
 - Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/10732093
 - Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/mthistle/

videos.curation_reason: Raw first-person account of brutal weather conditions that perfectly captures the race's challenging reputation.

videos.title: Rasputitsa - gravel racing in Vermont's northeast kingdom
videos.channel: Out of Collective - Ski & Outdoor Media Network
videos.description:
From the organizer:

"We are protagonists of community, freedom, and unity through cycling. 
Rasputitsa has a mission of cycling, community, and charity.  We call it the 3 C’s philosophy.

Rasputitsa is more than a gravel cycling race. It’s a homegrown self-supported challenge of the mind, body, and soul that instills people with a connected sense of place and purpose. It’s an authentic experience that embraces: The Unknown. Change. All people. All bikes.
We believe that all attendees should have an equal opportunity to participate in our event regardless of their race, color, religion, disability, age, gender identity, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status or national origin. We acknowledge both conceptual and practical barriers of entry into cycling for folks outside of the dominant group of participants. Part of our work is to understand how social structures create or enforce long established patterns of exclusivity in cycling. We hope to create a safe and welcoming space for athletes, staff, and spectators from different backgrounds, identities, and abilities at our event. We do not tolerate harassment or intimidation and anyone doing so will be asked to leave the event and will be reported to race officials and the governing body, USA Cycling. We look forward to growing the cycling community with you."

The Out of Collective is the source for the most relevant Ski, Bike & Outdoor Reviews, Content, and Podcasts in the industry. Join us! 

WEBSITE - http://outofpodcast.com
INSTAGRAM - https://www.instagram.com/outofcollective/
TWITTER - https://twitter.com/outofpodcast
FACEBOOK - https://www.facebook.com/TheOutofCollective
TIKTOK - https://www.tiktok.com/@outofpodcast
MERCH - http://getthecollective.com
Business Email: adam@outofpodcast.com

videos.title: Racing gravel on some pristine Vermont dirt at Rasputitsa 2023
videos.description:
10 hours driving for 57 miles of Vermont gravel and teammate time. I joined my Velocio // Exploro teammates for Rasputitsa in Burke, Vermont in late April. My teammate Sarah Lange won the Women's race and all four team riders placed in the top 15!

Follow me on instagram: https://www.instagram.com/watt_wagon/

If you have any video suggestions, please share in the comments below!


The following friends support me either financially or with free stuff, so huge thanks to these friends:

Velocio Apparel, 3T Bikes, SRAM, Schwalbe Tires, HUNT Wheels, Kask helmets, Koo Eyewear, Apidura Bags, Fizik, Muc Off, Kogel Bearings, and Wahoo.

videos.title: The Gravel Community
videos.description:
Rasputitsa is Russian for the mud season when roads become difficult to traverse. The Rasputitsa is a psychotic 45 mile, insane, drop to your knees and cry sufferfest with an absurdly section so difficult that people won't believe your stories called Cyberia. 

Video Production: Peregrine Productions LLC

videos.curation_reason: Recent first-person race recap with detailed course experience and good production quality covering the full 100k route.

quotes.text: It's only 57 miles but it's 7,000 feet of climbing and that's a lot for 57 miles.

This year was a true mental battle, to choose to start the race and to stay in as it rained, snowed, and sleeted on us. Wet gear, frozen fingers and toes, 42 miles, and 4700ft of climbing. All in temps of 37F to 41F degrees.
I took a whiskey shot at the last aid station and it was a very good choice paired with two chocolate chip cookies. Nothing says hydration like a hot dog.

key_challenges.name: Notorious BIG Hill
key_challenges.description: A significant climb at about 30 miles in with 3800 ft of climbing. Described as straight up for a long ways, with 5% grade feeling mellow compared to earlier climbs.

key_challenges.name: Siberia
key_challenges.description: A particularly rough section that riders specifically call out as difficult.

terrain_notes.text: Vermont gravel is hard packed, basically like a dirt highway according to riders on pre-race rides.
Roads are pretty smooth actually, with constant ups and downs throughout the course.
There was a muddy section the day before race day that left bikes very dirty.

race_day_tips.text: The race requires constant pedal to the metal max heart rate max power - it's relentless climbing.
Don't forget sunscreen even if weather looks good - riders were caught off guard by bright sunny conditions.
Taking whiskey shots and chocolate chip cookies at aid stations around mile 26 can be a good morale booster for the climbs ahead.

additional_quotes.text: I showed up at the front desk at 6:00 a.m. with a locked bike chain problem and hotel maintenance came out with bolt cutters to save my race - that's the kind of customer service you get here.
100% of what we make after we pay for the race itself goes to the Halo foundation and the Halo Foundation supports family struggling with the cost of cancer in Orleans County Vermont
It's only 57 miles but it's 7000 feet of climbing and that's a lot for 57 miles - I just did a parking lot bike wash with Dawn dish soap and there might still be soap on my chain

rider_intel.search_text: Rasputitsa in Burke, Vermont is a 46-57 mile gravel race with 5000-7000 feet of climbing that riders describe as relentlessly difficult. The course features hard-packed Vermont gravel that feels like a dirt highway, with constant ups and downs throughout. Key challenges include the Notorious BIG Hill around mile 30 with 3800 feet of climbing already completed, and a rough section called Siberia. Riders emphasize this requires constant maximum effort and heart rate. The race has grown from 50 to 500 participants and features excellent community support with people lining the entire course. Aid stations offer whiskey shots, cookies, and hot dogs. Weather can vary dramatically - past years have been freezing cold while recent editions have been sunny and warm. The terrain can be muddy the day before but dry up for race day. The event supports the Halo Foundation which helps families dealing with cancer costs in Orleans County Vermont.
